I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT 
A.  Overall Progress of the TA cluster 
1.  The  Technical  Assistance  Cluster  (C-TA)  for  Sustainable  Infrastructure  Assistance 
Program (SIAP) is financed by the Government of Australia through the Department of Foreign 
Affairs and Trade (DFAT) and administered by ADB1. The SIAP was approved on 13 June 2013 
and is due to close on 30 June 2019. As of 11 August 2017, total commitments are $12,352 million 
(77%) of the approved amount, $16,102,942, against an elapsed time of 67%. Disbursements are 
$6,258,992 (51%) of commitments. Nine subprojects have been approved, three of which have 
been closed. An additional 4 subprojects are planned ($3.25 million) and two ongoing TAs are 
earmarked for an increase in TA amount ($1.435 million). This TA proposal is one of those 
endorsed by the Steering Committee. SIAP is on track to meet its outcome and outputs. To date, 
SIAP has supported the preparation of approved projects and programs valued at nearly $3 billion 
($2,748 million in OCR and $1,128 million in cofinancing). 
 
B.  Subproject Outcome 
2.  The TA subproject’s outcome will be options for more innovative regional cooperation and 
integration (RCI) interventions on cross-border trade and investment for Indonesia. In December 
2016, Indonesian President Joko Widodo reiterated the Government’s plan to develop seven 
areas bordering parts of Malaysia, Timor-Leste and Papua New Guinea to promote commerce, 
reduce poverty, improve general living standards, and attract workers and their families to help 
reduce severe agglomeration in Java’s major urban centers. One area highlighted is to promote 
cross-border trade and investment to encourage the economic and social development of areas 
along the border, as cross-border cooperation opens opportunities for Indonesia’s inclusive 
economic growth objectives and facilitates regional cooperation.  
 
3.  The subproject is consistent with the Indonesia country partnership strategy 2016–2019 
priorities of improved infrastructure services and better economic growth. It directly responds to 
the crosscutting theme of regional cooperation. The subproject is also consistent the C-TA focus 
on priority areas of private sector development and regional cooperation through focused policy 
dialogue.2 The TA subproject fits the priorities of the C-TA, where ADB’s Indonesia country 
partnership strategy, development partnerships, private sector development including PPPs, 
knowledge management, governance and capacity development, and regional cooperation are 
supported. It particularly fits the C-TA’s identified priority of regional cooperation in Indonesia, 
given the government’s priority of improving cross-border economic cooperation with Indonesia’s 
neighboring countries, including Timor-Leste. 
4.  The TA subproject will provide critical inputs for a knowledge and support TA (KSTA) of 
the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)’s  Economic  Research  and  Regional  Cooperation 
Department (ERCD) on “Implementing the Regional Cooperation and Integration Operational 
Plan”.3 The KSTA aims to support the implementation of the Operational Plan for Regional 
Cooperation and Integration, 2016–2020 (RCI-OP) of ADB approved in September 2016.4 The 
                                                
1 ADB. 2013. Technical Assistance Cluster for Sustainable Infrastructure Assistance Program. Manila. (C-TA 0013-
INO). This technical assistance cluster, amounting to AU$20 million is financed by the Government of Australia, 
through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and administered by ADB. 
2  ADB. 2013. Technical Assistance Cluster for Sustainable Infrastructure Assistance Program. Manila (paragraph 10). 
3   TA 9350: “Implementing the Regional Cooperation and Integration Operational Plan”, which was approved on 31 July 
2017.         
4   ADB. 2016. Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2016-2020: Promoting Connectivity,

2 
TA subproject will provide Indonesia specific guidance and advice to inform the ERCD RCI 
operational plan  output 2: “competitiveness through new opportunities supported” under which a 
thematic study on Timor-Leste—(Eastern) Indonesia regional cooperation is being conducted. 
The subproject will focus on activities in Indonesia, linking with other policy and analytical work 
financed through the C-TA. 
 
C.  Subproject Outputs, Methods, and Activities   
5.  Output 1: Report on cross-border services for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) 
(covering financial and business development services). The study will examine opportunities and 
priorities for improving financial and business development services in Eastern Indonesia for 
greater cross-border trade and investment with Timor-Leste. Emphasis will be given to measures 
that will (i) promote SMEs that have a strong potential for trade growth and product diversification; 
(ii) increase SME inclusive trade in agricultural products, agroprocessing, and tourism services; 
(iii) support cross-border trade and investment in a cross-border economic zone between East 
Indonesia and Timor-Leste; and (iv) prepare and/or strengthen SMEs in Eastern Indonesia for 
cross-border  commerce.  This  work  will  include  both  quantitative  analysis  and  qualitative 
survey/interview work and consultation with key development partners and local enterprises. A 
pilot project and or investment will be identified. 
 
6.  Output  2:  Report  on  transport  connectivity  enhancement  to  support  trade  demand 
(covering roads and port gateways). The study will analyze infrastructure connectivity constraints 
by land (including last mile connectivity) and by sea/multi-modally. It will (i) focus on overland 
routes from Kupang to Dili over three identified overland crossing points and maritime connectivity 
between Kupang and Dili; and (ii) assess constraints in Kupang to act as a gateway port. The 
constraint analysis will take into consideration trade facilitation efficiency at cross-border points 
overland and ports, operations and maintenance constraints, and investment capacity constraints 
relative to trade volume forecasts. 
 
D.  Subproject Cost and Financing 
7.  The TA subproject is estimated to cost $220,000, of which $200,000 will be financed from 
the technical assistance cluster on a grant basis by DFAT, administered by ADB (footnote 1). The 
key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. The government will provide counterpart support 
in the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
E.  Subproject Implementation Arrangements 
8.  The TA subproject will be administered by Southeast Asia Department (SERD) with 
technical support from ERCD and in coordination with the Pacific Development. The executing 
agency of the subproject will be the Directorate of Financing and Risk Management, Ministry of 
Finance. Activities will be coordinated with relevant agencies such as the Ministry of Transport, 
Ministry of Trade, Ministry of Agriculture, Ministry of Tourism, Ministry of Cooperatives and Small 
and Medium Enterprises, and the National Planning Agency (BAPPENAS). The subproject will 
finance all activities in the DMF where these activities are conducted in Indonesia. 
                                                
    Competitiveness, Regional Public Goods, and Collective Action for Asia and the Pacific. Manila.

9.  Consulting services. It is estimated that a total of 8 person-months of international 
consulting services (2 consultants) and 8 person-months of national consulting services (2 
consultants) will be required to undertake the two studies. Consultants will be recruited through 
individual consultant selection in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2013, as amended from time to time).5 International consultants will work independently in close 
coordination with the project officer in ADB Headquarters. The national consultants will be based 
in Jakarta, Indonesia, providing administrative and  research assistance to the international 
consultants. The study team will collaborate closely with other related programs of DFAT in 
Indonesia,  particularly  on  transport  infrastructure,  agriculture,  economic  governance  and 
transnational crime.  
 
10.  Financier requirements. Regular progress reports will be submitted to DFAT as per 
agreement for the umbrella C-TA SIAP (footnote 1). 
                                                
5   Output-based/lump-sum contracts for consulting services under the TA will be considered in line with MTR Action 
    Plan Nos. 2.9.2. and 2.10.2. Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with ADB's Technical 
    Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).
